Merriam: Webster updated its definition and usage guidelines of the term "sexual preference" to say its use is "offensive" after the Oct. 13, 2020, confirmation hearing of Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
Barrett: s use of the term during the hearing incited anger in the LGBTQ community from those who argue that the phrase is outdated and linked to anti-gay sentiments.
The update to Merriam: Webster's definition was prompted by the public attention focused on the term after Barrett's comments and the subsequent questioning by members of the Senate Judiciary Committee on her position surrounding LGBTQ issues.
The dictionary publisher argued that usi: sexual preference" implies the suggestion that a person can choose who they are sexually or romantically attracted to, which is why it was deemed offensive and updated.
